snippet.title: Beyond the Buzzword: ‚ÄòSustainability‚Äô meets Artisanship
snippet.description:
‚ÄúSustainability‚Äù is gaining attention with consumers and organizations as society moves toward values of social fairness, and to protecting our environment.  This panel explores elements of sustainability through the lens of textile practitioners and educators.  What are the opportunities for artisanship to play a leading role in the development of sustainable and ethical textiles for garments and interiors?  What are the challenges in developing brands and businesses with a sustainability focus?

Previously the Founding Dean of the Dubai Institute of Design and Innovation, and Interim Dean of the Fashion Institute of Technology‚Äôs school of Art and Design, Sass Brown recently completed her Ph.D. at Manchester Metropolitan University on global artisanship and models of sustainable development. She is a writer, educator and activist with two books to her name: Eco Fashion and ReFashioned, and a Senior Lecturer on sustainable fashion for Kingston University London. Sass has has served as a sustainable design advisor to women‚Äôs cooperatives, educational institutions, governmental agencies, NGO‚Äôs and small and medium sized enterprises around the world.
Maheen Khan is the founder President of the Fashion Design Council of Bangladesh. She received a A Bachelor of Fine Arts from Otis Parsons School of Art and Design with a major in surface pattern design for the fashion and interior design industry. She is pioneer designer who started her career with Aarong a social enterprise of BRAC in 1986. She has worked with skill development and income generation of rural artisans for over 36 years. Her design interventions revived age old crafts with functional modern aesthetics. Her work I was truly multifaceted and addressed a wide range of products jewellery, terracotta, leather, jute, metal crafts, printing, embroidery and hand loom. Today as the owner and designer of Studio Mayasir, she continues to work with traditional textile techniques that promotes local expertise. With fashion produced ethically and with sustainable goals she would like to take her local ideas global, and in doing so she wants to partner with  local artisans for all her design activities.

Laura Rana was inspired to start Khushi Kantha (‚ÄòHappy Blanket‚Äô) by the birth of her half-British, half-Bangladeshi twin daughters and her long-standing dream to use everything she‚Äôs learned from twelve years of working in the international development and humanitarian sectors in Bangladesh, to create opportunities for other mothers to provide for their children with dignity. Khushi Kantha creates sustainable, multi-purpose baby blankets, hand-stitched from reclaimed and ethically-sourced cotton and embroidered with empowerment by mothers in Bangladesh. Operating as a social enterprise, Khushi Kantha is reworking the Bengali kantha tradition of repurposing old cotton saris into ultra-soft, multi-layered blankets to meet global hygiene and safety standards while retaining the principles of ‚Äòreclaim-repurpose-reuse‚Äô and bringing the rich handmade textiles heritage of Bangladesh to a wider audience. 

This panel‚Äôs moderator, Cathy Stevulak is a filmmaker and international program consultant. Her interest in textiles and the advancement of artisan enterprise, particularly in South Asia, led her to direct and produce the award-winning film, THREADS. Stevulak‚Äôs interest in sustainable fashion and human development stems from a young age when she and her mother upcycled and made clothing. Prior to becoming a filmmaker, Stevulak lived around the world while working with the United Nations Development Program in Bangladesh, the Canadian International Development Agency, NATO and CARE.

snippet.title: Unboxing Brother Vellies by CFDA Designer Aurora James (2024)
snippet.description:
MalikaB Unboxes Brother Vellies by Aurora James

How exciting, I was blessed enough to shop the sample sale two years in a row. I definitely think this will be an annual treat. Why not? Brother Vellies is a black owned brand by awarded and honored Canadian, but Brooklyn based designer Aurora James. She has a boutique in New York City. They shoes are handmade in Africa and the artisans who create the pieces are extremely talented. Be sure to check out her IG page: @brothervellies and @aurorajames to find out more. www.brothervellies.com
If you could like and subscribe to the Channel, that‚Äôs always lovely and helps it to grow. Thanks so much for your support! I‚Äôm an avid Fashion Enthusiast and Stylist of Myself and these are the pieces that I select that inspire and communicate with my soul. I hope you love them too.

-MalikaB.

snippet.title: SOKO :: We Might Be Dead By Tomorrow (Official Video)
snippet.description:
"We Might Be Dead By Tomorrow", taken from Soko's debut album "I Thought I Was An Alien" : http://smarturl.it/soko-album 
Subscribe to the channel: https://soko.lnk.to/ytsub 
Listen to Soko's essentials here: https://soko.lnk.to/musicvideo

Directed by: SOKO
Filmed by: Soko, Adarsha Benjamin, Teddy Cecil & Ericka Clevenger
Edited by: Jimmy Mehiel 
Lovers: Meghan Edwards & Soko
Make up: Sweet P
Skulls by @Alterian

THANK YOU: Tony Gardner, Meghan Edwards, Sweet P, Ericka Clevenger, Teddy Cecil, Jimmy, Sam Spiegel, Adarsha Benjamin

Shot in Los Angeles, April 2012

Follow Soko:
http://www.facebook.com/soko
Twitter / Instagram : @SokoTheCat

‚Üì LYRICS ‚Üì

Give me all your love
'Cause for all we know
We might be dead by tomorrow

I can't go on wasting my time
Adding scars to my heart
'Cause all I hear is
I'm not ready now

And I can tell
That you didn't had
To face your mother
Losing her lover
Without saying goodbye
'Cause she didn't had time

I don't want to judge
What's in your heart
But if you're not ready for love
How can you be ready for life?
How can you be ready for life?

So let's love fully
And let's love loud
Let's love now
'Cause soon enough we'll die

#Soko #WeMightBeDeadByTomorrow

snippet.title: Care Assistant Interview Questions and Interview
snippet.description:
In this video, Faisal Nadeem shared 10 most important care assistant interview questions and answers or healthcare assistant job interview questions and answers or care assistant job interview questions and answers uk or healthcare assistant interview questions nhs or healthcare assistant interview questions and answers for freshers or healthcare assistant interview in newzealand completely explained by @Knowledge Topper with suitable examples.

Q1) Tell me about yourself.
Answer: I‚Äôm compassionate, hardworking, and dedicated to supporting people with dignity and respect in their daily lives.

Q2) What‚Äôs your greatest strength?
Answer: I‚Äôm patient, a good listener, and always attentive to the needs and comfort of those I care for.

Q3) What‚Äôs your biggest weakness?
Answer: I used to hesitate asking for help, but I‚Äôve learned that teamwork leads to better care.

Q4) Why do you want this job?
Answer: I enjoy helping others, and this role lets me make a positive impact on someone‚Äôs well-being every day.

Q5) Where do you see yourself in 5 years?
Answer: I see myself gaining more experience and possibly training for a senior or specialized care role.

Q6) Why should we hire you?
Answer: I‚Äôm dependable, empathetic, and committed to delivering high-quality personal care with respect and kindness.

Q7) How do you handle pressure?
Answer: I stay calm, prioritize tasks, and focus on giving the best care even in busy or challenging situations.

Q8) How do you handle failure?
Answer: I reflect, learn from it, and use it as a chance to improve both my skills and approach.

Q9) What are your salary expectations?
Answer: I‚Äôm open to a fair and competitive offer based on the responsibilities of the role.

Q10) Do you have any questions for us?
Answer: What kind of support, training, and progression opportunities are available for care assistants?

snippet.title: Why Gen Z Is Facing A Career APOCALYPSE
snippet.description:
Gen Z is entering the worst job market in decades, facing unprecedented challenges when it comes to landing a career. As entry level jobs become increasingly competitive and fewer in number, young job seekers are struggling to navigate a job market that no longer plays by the same rules. The traditional path of going to college, graduating, and securing a stable first job out of college is being replaced by a maze of confusing application processes, unpaid internships, and automated rejections. For many members of Gen Z, the job search has become more about endurance than opportunity, with outdated systems and unrealistic expectations standing in the way of genuine career development.

Ghost jobs, or job listings that companies never intend to fill, continue to flood online platforms, wasting the time and energy of recent graduates who are eager to prove themselves. Platforms like LinkedIn have added another layer of complexity, where algorithmic suppression and a bias toward continuous employment make it even harder for Gen Z to stand out. Crafting a resume, curating a digital profile, and applying to hundreds of jobs has become the new normal‚Äîyet meaningful responses are rare. Many are told they lack the right experience, even for jobs labeled as entry level, while others are dismissed for employment gaps or jobs that ‚Äúdon‚Äôt align‚Äù with their desired career path.

This isn‚Äôt just about Gen Z being young or inexperienced‚Äîit‚Äôs about the systems in place that no longer support growth. Employers increasingly expect applicants to arrive fully trained, yet invest less and less in job training, mentorship, or on-the-job development. Even unpaid internships, once seen as a stepping stone, have become a luxury not everyone can afford. The gap between those who can afford to work for free and those who need immediate income continues to widen, creating a new kind of economic barrier to entry.

For many members of Gen Z, the first job out of college feels like an impossible achievement. Even with advanced degrees, certifications, and side projects, many are met with silence. Automated tracking systems filter resumes before a human ever sees them. Cover letters feel obsolete. Phone interviews are replaced with digital assessments. And all the while, Gen Z is told that the job market is strong, despite mounting personal debt, record high housing costs, and stagnant wages that don‚Äôt reflect the cost of living.

In this environment, building a career feels more like surviving a collapse. Networking has turned into unpaid labor. Career advice often feels disconnected from reality. The optimism once tied to starting a new job is now clouded by anxiety, burnout, and doubt. The entry level job, once a rite of passage, now feels like a vanishing illusion‚Äîreplaced by an endless cycle of unpaid labor, rejection, and confusion. For Gen Z, this isn‚Äôt just a job search. It‚Äôs a reckoning with a system that promised opportunity and delivered obstruction. The result is a generation forced to adapt in ways no other generation had to‚Äîfighting not just for work, but for a future.

localized.title: Why Gen Z Is Facing A Career APOCALYPSE
localized.description:
Gen Z is entering the worst job market in decades, facing unprecedented challenges when it comes to landing a career. As entry level jobs become increasingly competitive and fewer in number, young job seekers are struggling to navigate a job market that no longer plays by the same rules. The traditional path of going to college, graduating, and securing a stable first job out of college is being replaced by a maze of confusing application processes, unpaid internships, and automated rejections. For many members of Gen Z, the job search has become more about endurance than opportunity, with outdated systems and unrealistic expectations standing in the way of genuine career development.

Ghost jobs, or job listings that companies never intend to fill, continue to flood online platforms, wasting the time and energy of recent graduates who are eager to prove themselves. Platforms like LinkedIn have added another layer of complexity, where algorithmic suppression and a bias toward continuous employment make it even harder for Gen Z to stand out. Crafting a resume, curating a digital profile, and applying to hundreds of jobs has become the new normal‚Äîyet meaningful responses are rare. Many are told they lack the right experience, even for jobs labeled as entry level, while others are dismissed for employment gaps or jobs that ‚Äúdon‚Äôt align‚Äù with their desired career path.

This isn‚Äôt just about Gen Z being young or inexperienced‚Äîit‚Äôs about the systems in place that no longer support growth. Employers increasingly expect applicants to arrive fully trained, yet invest less and less in job training, mentorship, or on-the-job development. Even unpaid internships, once seen as a stepping stone, have become a luxury not everyone can afford. The gap between those who can afford to work for free and those who need immediate income continues to widen, creating a new kind of economic barrier to entry.

For many members of Gen Z, the first job out of college feels like an impossible achievement. Even with advanced degrees, certifications, and side projects, many are met with silence. Automated tracking systems filter resumes before a human ever sees them. Cover letters feel obsolete. Phone interviews are replaced with digital assessments. The optimism once tied to starting a new job is now clouded by anxiety, burnout, and doubt. The entry level job, once a rite of passage, now feels like a vanishing illusion‚Äîreplaced by an endless cycle of unpaid labor, rejection, and confusion. For Gen Z, this isn‚Äôt just a job search. It‚Äôs a reckoning with a system that promised opportunity and delivered obstruction. The result is a generation forced to adapt in ways no other generation had to‚Äîfighting not just for work, but for a future.

My parents forced me away from my first and only real love at 17, moving us across the country. It was devastating to both of us. We met us several times over the course of our lives but ended out too damaged by what life had thrown at us. Then one day  she reached out on facebook and ignited a nuclear bomb of penned up emotions. It is now 41 years since I first had to say goodbye. Last Monday I asked her to marry me. She said yes. Life moves on, never let go. First love, real love, it really lasts forever no matter what. It endures through anything and it is quite possible to reignite at a moments notice. If you have your first real love out there, keep in touch. Be friends. Be happy if they are happy even if it is not with you. The right timing is all you need. I wish this chance for everyone.
